summary: This is a detailed Palm Beach Police Department incident report (Case No. 1-05-000368) documenting the investigation into allegations that Jeffrey Epstein sexually abused underage girls at his Palm Beach residence. The report includes initial reports, victim and witness interviews, surveillance logs, trash pulls, execution of a search warrant, and interactions with the State Attorney's Office regarding potential charges and grand jury proceedings.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Wealthy Palm Beach resident accused of paying underage girls for massages that escalated to sexual acts. The primary subject of the investigation.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Identified as Epstein's main assistant who traveled with him, arranged for girls, and was present during incidents. Described as a white female with hair.

persons.name: Sarah Kellen
persons.context: Referred to as 'Nadia' or 'Epstein's assistant' in the report. Described as a white female who set up massage rooms, instructed girls, and arranged appointments.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.context: Former houseman for Epstein (Nov 2004 - May 2005) who provided detailed testimony about daily massages, young girls, paying girls, and cleaning sex toys.

persons.name: Juan Alessi
persons.context: Employed by Epstein for 11 years (1994-2002). Interviewed with his wife and described massages with young girls and cleaning vibrators.

persons.name: Larry Morrison
persons.context: Listed as flight engineer on Epstein's plane (N908JE) in a retrieved itinerary from a trash pull.

persons.name: Guy Fronstin
persons.context: Attorney representing Jeffrey Epstein during the investigation. Communicated with detectives, relayed messages from Epstein, and later stated he was fired from representation.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: High-profile attorney involved in the case. Provided material on victims to the State Attorney's Office and participated in meetings regarding the investigation.

persons.name: Jack Goldberger
persons.context: Became Epstein's attorney of record after Guy Fronstin was fired. Met with the State Attorney's Office regarding the case.

persons.name: Roy Black
persons.context: Miami attorney who directed private investigators working for Epstein's defense team.

persons.name: Lana Belohlavek
persons.context: Prosecutor assigned to the Epstein case. Made decisions about grand jury presentations and plea offers.

persons.name: Daliah Weiss
persons.context: Prosecutor initially assigned to the case. Removed because her husband worked for Epstein's attorney Jack Goldberger.

persons.name: Barry Krischer
persons.context: Palm Beach County State Attorney who made final decisions on whether to take the case to a grand jury or pursue charges.

persons.name: David Norr
persons.context: Contractor observed conducting remodeling at Epstein's Palm Beach residence in 2006.

persons.name: Leslie Wexner
persons.context: CEO of The Limited Inc. His private plane (Gulfstream 4) was observed at Palm Beach airport, but he was not directly involved in the incidents.

persons.name: Ivan Robles
persons.context: Licensed private investigator whose vehicle was seen photographing the victim's family home.

persons.name: Zachary Bechard
persons.context: Licensed private investigator employed by Candor Investigations who aggressively followed the victim's family.

persons.name: Tim Valentine
persons.context: Investigator with the State Attorney's Office who notified police of the grand jury cancellation.

connections.description: Maxwell is identified as Epstein's main assistant who traveled with him, arranged for girls, and was present during massage sessions.
Kellen (referred to as Nadia) is described as an assistant who set up massage rooms, instructed girls, and arranged appointments for Epstein.
Rodriguez was Epstein's houseman/house manager for six months, responsible for paying girls, cleaning sex toys, and maintaining a cash fund for Epstein.
Alessi was Epstein's houseman for 11 years, responsible for preparing the house, setting up massage tables, and cleaning after massages.
Fronstin served as Epstein's defense attorney during the police investigation, communicating with detectives on his behalf.
Dershowitz provided legal advice and defense strategy for Epstein, including providing material on victims to prosecutors.
Kellen is described by multiple victims as the person who contacted them, arranged appointments, and instructed them on what to do during massages.
Maxwell is identified by some victims as the person who approached them about working for Epstein and making money.
Rodriguez testified that he would pay girls when Epstein wasn't available, deliver gifts/roses, and drive girls home.

events.title: Initial Victim Incident
events.description: The 14-year-old victim is taken to Epstein's house by Sarah Kellen and another female. She provides a massage during which Epstein masturbates and pays her $300.

events.title: Initial Police Report
events.description: The victim's stepmother contacts Palm Beach Police to report that her 14-year-old stepdaughter may have been sexually abused by a wealthy man in Palm Beach.

events.title: Photo Lineup Identification
events.description: The 14-year-old victim positively identifies Jeffrey Epstein from a photo lineup.

events.title: Search Warrant Execution
events.description: Palm Beach Police execute a search warrant at 358 El Brillo Way. They seize computers, hidden cameras, photographs of naked women, sex toys, lubricants, and other evidence.

events.title: Grand Jury Cancellation
events.description: The State Attorney's Office cancels the scheduled grand jury session after making a plea offer to Epstein's defense team.

events.title: Arrest Warrant Requests
events.description: Detective submits arrest warrant requests for Jeffrey Epstein (4 counts of unlawful sexual activity with minors, 1 count lewd molestation), Sarah Kellen (principal charges), and another recruiter.

events.title: Epstein's Arrest Reported
events.description: Newspaper article reports Jeffrey Epstein's arrest, prompting additional victims to come forward to police.

events.title: Additional Victim Comes Forward
events.description: A woman comes forward after reading about Epstein's arrest, stating she was a victim at age 17 and that Epstein knew her age.

locations: 358 El Brillo Way, Palm Beach, FL 33480 (Epstein's primary residence)
457 Madison Avenue, New York, NY (Epstein's business address)
keyFacts: The investigation began in March 2005 after a report that a 14-year-old girl was paid $300 for a sexual massage at Epstein's Palm Beach home.

Multiple victims (at least 17 listed in the report) described similar patterns: being recruited by other girls or assistants, providing massages to Epstein while he was naked or in a towel, Epstein masturbating during the massages, and payment of $200-$400.

Epstein's employees, including housemen Alfredo Rodriguez and Juan Alessi, provided corroborating testimony about daily massages with young girls, cleaning sex toys, and Epstein's practices of paying girls.
The State Attorney's Office delayed prosecution, canceled a scheduled grand jury in April 2006, and considered a plea deal before ultimately pursuing charges.
Epstein's defense team employed private investigators who aggressively followed and intimidated victims and their families during the investigation.
